name: places/ChIJcS3x-QFZwokRPVALHyhhtkg
formattedAddress: 51 E 44th St, New York, NY 10017, USA
adrFormatAddress: 51 E 44th St, New York, NY 10017-3861, USA

originalText.text:
For those in search of other New York sites to Nathan Hale, head NE to 66th Street and Third Ave where you will find another plaque to Hale, this time sadly it marks the vicinity of where he was hanged and actually gave his life for his country. There is also a statue of Hale in City Hall Park to the south (a photo of that statue included here, keep in mind that the statue itself is generally not accessible as it is behind the City Hall security gate and guard house). You will also find adjacent to City Hall Park along Broadway two stone plaques in the sidewalk marking the approximate locations of the Bridewell, the notorious prison that opened in 1775 as well as the British Barracks (City Hall Park is basically along Broadway between Chambers and Park Place; you can take the N, R, or W yellow line subway to City Hall). If you want to see what these look like check out this Atlas Obscura piece: https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/nathan-hale-hanging-site
I wonder just how many commuting New Yorkers and tourists NEVER stop to read this plaque or that at 66th Street? I’ve stood nearby on occasion and for every person that does stop hundreds walk by it. New York has a dearth of Revolutionary sites, what remains are few and far between, including the structures that survive—unlike Boston and Philadelphia.
